{"step_by_step_thinking": "Based on the information provided, the rectovaginal swab culture grew bacitracin-resistant colonies of gram-positive cocci with surrounding areas of clear hemolysis. This is suggestive of Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection. GBS is a common cause of neonatal sepsis and can be vertically transmitted during delivery. The most appropriate intervention to decrease vertical transmission of GBS is to administer intrapartum antibiotics. The recommended antibiotic for GBS prophylaxis is intravenous penicillin or ampicillin. Therefore, the correct answer is B. Administer ampicillin intrapartum.", "answer_choice": "B"}
